[{"id":"TP-1","entityId":"2-1","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"TP"},{"name":"summary","value":"False alarm "class, interface, or method should not be extended""},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"root"},{"name":"created","value":"1563796512582"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"1"},{"name":"description","value":"

What steps will reproduce the issue?
import com.intellij.openapi.roots.libraries.LibraryTable

class A : LibraryTable.Listener {
}
What is the expected result?
nothing
What happens instead?
Inspection "class, interface, or method should not be extended" warn : "Interface com.intellij.openapi.roots.libraries.LibraryTable must not be implemented"

"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"root"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"root"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"0"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"root"},{"name":"markdown","value":"true"},{"name":"wikified","value":"true"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"updated","value":"1565081189563"},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Submitted"],"valueId":["Submitted"],"color":null},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"root","fullName":"root"}]}],"comment":[],"tag":[]}, {"id":"TP-2","entityId":"2-2","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"TP"},{"name":"summary","value":"Support internal protected visibility"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"root"},{"name":"created","value":"1563796681420"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"2"},{"name":"description","value":"

Big libraries like kotlinx.couroutines would greatly benefit from internal protected visibility that restricts access only to inheriting classes in the same module. The reason is that the library might define some auxiliary class like Base with a bunch protected methods that have final override in some user-visible open class Derived, which is open by itself. However, we don't want user-defined classes that override Derived to be able to access those protected method.

The implementation of internal protected could have used the same java-name mangling approach that is used by internal to reduce the likelyhood of abuse of those methods from Java code.

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1565960261248,"updated":1565960369081,"permittedGroup":null,"markdown":true,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"KT-28295","entityId":"25-2174051","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"KT"},{"name":"summary","value":"Use `languageSettings` for a quick fix to enable experimental features in multiplatform projects"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Liliia Abdulina"},{"name":"created","value":"1542614984677"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"28295"},{"name":"description","value":"
In a new multiplatform project, write the following code in the common module: inline class Foo(val i: Int)
IDE highlights inline keyword, suggesting enable or disable inline classes support in the current module.
Currently, the "enable" QF option inserts the following code into build.gradle file, given that there are jvmApp, jsApp, iosApp platform-specific source sets: 
kotlin {
    /* ...some other project configurations... */
    targets {
        /* ...some other presets configurations... */
        configure([jvmApp, jsApp, iosApp]) {
            tasks.getByName(compilations.main.compileKotlinTaskName).kotlinOptions {
                freeCompilerArgs = ["-XXLanguage:+InlineClasses"]
            }
        }
    }
}
— wich isn't quite convinient because of two reasons:
  1. It doesn't enable the experimental feature (inline classes) for the common module.
  2. If there are android targets among others, the build fails on them with Could not get unknown property 'main' for KotlinJvmAndroidCompilation container of type org.gradle.api.internal.FactoryNamedDomainObjectContainer. error.

It'd be more consistent (with the documentation as well) to configure such features as follows:
kotlin.sourceSets.all {
    it.languageSettings.enableLanguageFeature("InlineClasses")
}

  • IDEA 2018.2.6 Release (182.5107.16), Kotlin plugin 1.3.20-dev-1845
  • Android Studio 3.2.1 (181.5540.7.32.5056338), Kotlin plugin 1.3.20-dev-1845

e: java.lang.IllegalStateException: no function <init> in org.jetbrains.kotlin.ir.declarations.impl.IrFileImpl@a7e362


Execution failed for task ':linkReleaseFrameworkIosArm64'.
> Process 'command '/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_162.jdk/Contents/Home/bin/java'' finished with non-zero exit value 2

Turns out this is the piece of code that triggers the compiler crash:

@Serializable
class TransformerRule {
    @Serializer(forClass = TransformerRule::class)
    companion object : KSerializer<TransformerRule> {}
}

Doing it this way fixes the issue:

@Serializable
data class TransformerRule {
    @Serializer(forClass = TransformerRule::class)
    object TransformerRuleSerializer: KSerializer<TransformerRule> {}
}

It should convert single-line lambda expression

list.map { item -> item.operation }

to a multi-line one:

list.map { item ->
   item.operation 
}

and vice-versa

May be useful when your single-line lambda becomes too complex and you want to make it multi-line

to allow using kotlinx-serialization, eap versions of kotlin and other plugins without the buildscript block

currently this configuration is required (example for kotlin 1.3 and kotlinx-serialization)

build.gradle.kts

plugins {
    kotlin("jvm") version Versions.kotlin
    id("kotlinx-serialization") version Versions.kotlin
}

settings.gradle.kts

pluginManagement {
    repositories {
        maven(url = "http://dl.bintray.com/kotlin/kotlin-eap")
        // mavenLocal()
        gradlePluginPortal()
    }
    resolutionStrategy {
        eachPlugin {
            if (requested.id.id == "org.jetbrains.kotlin.jvm") {
                useModule("org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:${requested.version}")
            }
            if (requested.id.id == "kotlinx-serialization") {
                useModule("org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-serialization:${requested.version}")
            }
        }
    }
}

rootProject.name = "sampleProject"

with plugin markers existing, the resolutionStrategy block would not be required, simplifying configurations

and in combination with responsibly using buildSrc for keeping plugin and dependency versions organized it leads to much more organized gradle scripts
I'd like to advocate for a ecosystem of readable buildscripts :P

gradle's documentation states :
This allows Gradle to do smart things such as:

  • Optimize the loading and reuse of plugin classes.
  • Allow different plugins to use different versions of dependencies.
  • Provide editors detailed information about the potential properties and values in the buildscript for editing assistance.

additionally i would suggest for example gradle configurations to be updated to include instructions for using pluginManagement
eg:

  • https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlinx.coroutines/blob/master/README.md#gradle (ext.kotlin_version should probably not be used .. instead a constant in buildSrc or in the plgins block)
  • https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlinx.serialization/blob/master/README.md#gradlejvm
  • https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlinx.serialization/blob/master/docs/eap13.md
  • https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlinx.atomicfu/blob/master/README.md#jvm
  • https://github.com/Kotlin/dokka/blob/master/README.md#using-dokka

and a search query for validation later: https://github.com/search?q=org%3AKotlin+buildscript+extension%3Amd&type=Code

0 until collection.size
and
0..collection.size-1
convert to
collection.indices

Note: in for loop like this
for (index in 0 until collection.size) {
    println(collection[index])
}

it's better to replace it directly with iteration over collection without suggested indices:
for (element in collection) {
    println(element)
}

For Kotlin 1.3.50-eap-5:

file.kt:

fun question(subject: String, names: Array<String> = emptyArray()): String {
    return buildString { // breakpoint here
        append("$subject?") // actual stop
        for (name in names)
            append(" $name?")
    }
}

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    println(question("Subject", args))    
}

Here aren't technical issue except may be user might not expect this behaviour. Technically at this line there're no any instructions which behave to call-site only from inlined function in this case from buildString, so that why debugger resolve "actual stop" as the nearest possible point on the call-site. Dirty solution could be generating some nop surviving through optimisation pipeline on a call-site with with corresponding location information, but I prefer to avoid such hacks to code generator.

Short: IntelliJ is too slows and take freezes in case of just Enum changes.

Details

Preconditions:

  • Create enumeration with ~200-300 values (I use it to define Oracle database procedures).
  • Use all values of this file in the other classes (for my project, there are about 200 classes, who use values of this enumeration, e.g. each of them have code like this: private val something = MyEnum.Value123
  • My *.kt file has only this enumeration and zero other classes/functions
  • Totally my project has ~1500 kotlin classes

Code change logic:

  • Sometimes I have to define one more value
  • Actions to do this:
    • Open file with this huge enumeration
    • Duplicate line (e.g. press Ctrl-D) --- this action drops highlight of the part of file
    • Change the enumeration value name --- and IntelliJ Idea slows down here too.

kotlin
private tailrec fun injectProperties(properties: Map<String, String>, str: String, depth: Int = 0): String {
            if (depth < 0) throw IllegalArgumentException("Negative depth")
            if (depth > 50) return str
            val propertyRegex = Regex("\\$\\{([^}]+)}")
            val found = propertyRegex.findAll(str).also { if (it.none()) return str }
            return injectProperties(
                properties,
                found.fold(str) { acc, curr ->
                    val propertyName = curr.groupValues[1]
                    val propertyValue = properties[propertyName] ?: return@fold acc
                    return@fold acc.replace(curr.value, propertyValue)
                },
                depth + 1
            )
        }

Every time I successfully connected debugger to process, I see frames in this fun or Regex.
depth is always 0, str is always the same. Also, it shouldn't hang even without depth guard.

This process yet still alive and I can provide some info you ask.
